ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to drive boats and stuff. Pretty fun

I learned how to properly/safely navigate a vessel. I also learned more about the rules of the road which I knew some but not all of it. Over all, I feel more confident in navigating a vessel through different situations.
I learned the skills and technology that sailors use to navigate.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You will gain a lot of insight into how navigation works in the Surface Warfare community. That being said, you are in for a few lessons that will have no impact on the course or navigation, and other lessons that assume a level of understanding that only comes from spending time in the fleet. Expect to actually have to spend time on the class, and expect it to be difficult if you do not take the time to learn your stuff.

I think the strength of this course was the preparedness of LT Pettenski. The content was also distributed in a timely manner and all the resources were super helpful. 
I would say a weakness would be that the lectures weren't recorded. I feel like one good thing that has come of zoom school is that recorded lectures are great to have to go back to.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A class that is supposed to simulate in-person activities and relies on things like charts and maneuvering boards will obviously struggle online, but it was especially difficult to explain concepts relating to maneuvering over Zoom.
I still believe the lectures could have been recorded. I know it was limited due to covid, but it would have been helpful to have more in person chart labs.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Required for Navy, but interesting if you have a desire to be on a boat in the future. There are probably better ways to get this information, but if you have the time and want to meet at 7:30 in the morning, feel free to take it.
I would recommend it if someone was interested in the course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had two in-person labs.
In-person virtual lab and chart lab.
